@Arfoli @realmoney Apr 09, 2020 | 07:55 AM EDT DOUG KASS CAT Is Still a DOG * On March 16 I took a trading long rental in Caterpillar - selling it out shortly thereafter for a profit * I took a trading short rental in CAT, at the close yesterday * CAT's shares have climbed

from under $90 to over $127 since March 16th Over the years, I have made money on the short side on several occasions in Caterpillar (CAT) and I recently (profitably) purchased a trading long rental in CAT. On March 16, 2020 CAT traded under $90/share, the next day I went long

on a trading basis. The shares closed at $127.40 yesterday, up +$5.50 on the day. According to our dealer contacts, it is likely that dealer sales, and equipment orders to CAT, will be weaker for longer (well into 2021) than the consensus expects. Of note, used product pricing

(even on low hour used equipment) has begun to erode quickly. Construction halts based on Covid-19 restrictions and an inability to get working permits are backing up business far worse that sell side analysts expect. Mining activity has been noted by many, in the U.S. and non

U.S., to be weakening badly. Based on my analysis, consensus EPS forecasts for the next three years are materially too high - and I expect the analyst community to cut estimates in the days and weeks ahead. There is a broad range of sell side 2020, 2021 and 2022 EPS estimates
DM me your email acct.

rolling stone/But that’s not how it used to be.” We made mistakes of governance in the past but one would hope we learned from them – but sadly we learned nothing. We wasted the decade since the last crisis weakening our economy by borrowing trillions of dollars to solve a

debt crisis, convincing ourselves that debts don’t have to be repaid and that we don’t have to answer for our sins. And the first time we were tested again, we sinned on a much larger scale. We should be ashamed of ourselves, but sadly we are no longer capable of shame.

We better start figuring out pretty quick what we are capable of, however, because all the empty shibboleths about American greatness aren’t going to pay our bills when they come due. And they will come due regardless of what the yahoos running this country would like us to

believe. My bet is they come due in hyperinflation after a debt deflationary shock, but regardless of what happens first, everybody better start preparing. @jimcramer @tomkeene @lizclaman @riskreversal @guyadami @terranovajoe

@beckyquick @andrewrsorkin We are looking at annual deficits running at $2 trillion a year, a $30 trillion federal deficit and a $10 trillion Federal Reserve balance sheet, numbers that will put Japan to shame. The difference is that unlike Japan, which is a racially and socially

homogeneous society, ours is a racially and socially divided society where people value freethinking, non-conformity and freedom from government intrusion into their lives. Things are going to get very ugly, and they deserve to. Rescue the airlines? Where does it all stop @bec

financial instruments their inherent differences no longer matter), this unnecessary step was a corrupt back-door bailout of the private equity industry, which was sitting on $300 billion of dry powder at year end. Let airlines fail and emerge out of bankruptcy, Becky:

There is no conceivable policy justification for bailing out industries that leveraged up the American economy into the fragile condition that rendered so many businesses (like airlines) incapable of sustaining themselves through a shutdown; the only rationale is the same kind

of political influence peddling that rewarded Wall Street at the expense of Main Street after the Great Financial Crisis a decade ago. The right thing to do is to leave the private equity and real estate industries to the mercy of market forces, not to perpetuate the “head’s I

win, tail’s you lose” (“I” being their executives, “you” being their investors and society at large) that enabled these two sectors to enrich themselves and bury the economy in debt over the last thirty years. These industries could not achieve this, however, without the

enthusiastic support of politicians granting them egregious tax breaks in exchange for campaign contributions, Wall Street, institutional investors incapable of distinguishing nominal from risk-adjusted returns, and the financial media. There is no turning back now. Our economy
is nationalized with the government giving lip service to helping workers and lower income people while showering the real money on the rich and powerful.
